Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Epifluorescence Microscope for Research and Education at the University of Oregon CAMCOR Facility
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) programs, the University of Oregon will acquire an epifluorescence microscope. The instrument consists of a light source and a microscope. The microscope detects the light that is emitted (fluoresced) from a sample after irradiation by the light source. The instrument will enable experiments focused on imaging of live cells. It will be used by undergraduate and graduate students in their research. This training will assist them in future careers as live cell imaging is widely used in the biotechnology industry. The acquisition will be incorporated in community outreach activities including K-12 programs.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) creating imaging tools for hydrogen sulfide detection and delivery; (b) making molecular probes for small molecule/ion recognition; (c) preparing Pt(II) reagents for RNA biochemistry; and (d) using carbon quantum dots to engineer nanostructures for biomedical imaging.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF MRI award funded the purchase of a new Leica DMI8 epifluorescent microscope that supports users in the Chemistry and Physics departments at the University of Oregon. Major components of the acquired system include of a broad-wavelength light source to illuminate samples, microscope, lenses, filters, high-sensitivity detector, incubation stage, automated stage controls, anti-vibration table, and software to acquire and analyze images. The primary use of the microscope is monitor live cells during the course of different types of experiments. These experiments include monitor the fluorescence (light emitted) by small molecules that react with and label biomolecules of interest, cell migration rates and dynamics, and cell adhesion to complex synthetic microstructures. Importantly, the NSF-funded systems enables experiments over different time ranges, ranging from only a few minutes to up to 24 hours of constant monitoring. In addition, the light sources and filters for the microscope enable experiments with non-traditional or recently-developed fluorophores with unique optical and photophysical properties. The presence of this microscope has enabled new research that was not possible prior to this grant. The results obtained on this system has also increased the impact of NSF-funded research within the Chemistry and Physics departments. Specifically, this microscope has supported developing new fluorescent molecules for hydrogen sulfide detection and delivery, developing and testing new fluorescent molecules for live-cell imaging, preparing and monitoring Pt(II) reagents for RNA biochemistry, and using new carbon quantum dots to engineer nanostructures for new imaging experiments. In addition to the scientific impacts, access to the microscope has provided undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctoral researchers training related to fluorescence microscopy, which not only furthers their individual research projects but also contributes to their scientific professional development.
